questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a forensic examination in a case involving a late-term abortion. To assist in determining the gestational age of the fetus at the time of the abortion, the medical officer is reviewing the mother's medical records for documented physical examination findings. External ballottement is a technique used to assess fetal development. After how many weeks of gestation can external ballottement typically be performed in a normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

External ballottement, a technique where the fetus can be felt to rebound against the examiner's fingers during a pelvic examination, is typically possible after about 20 weeks of gestation. This is when the fetus is large enough to be palpated through the abdominal wall.

 

Demonstration

 

  • Vaginal/internal ballottement: Two fingers are inserted into the anterior fornix and a sudden upward motion given. This causes the fetus to move up in the liquor amnii and after a moment, the fetus drops down on the fingers, like a ball bouncing back.
  • External ballottement: A sudden motion is given to the abdominal wall covering the uterus, in a few seconds the rebound of the fetus can be felt.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ballottement (toss up like a ball): This is positive during the 4th–5th month of pregnancy as the fetus is small in relation to the amount of amniotic fluid present. This is a useful clinical sign for assessing fetal development around the midpoint of the gestation period.

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 394

choices.text: They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells along the path of electric current.
They indicate the path taken by the discharge along the major blood vessels
They gradually fade within 24 – 48 hours if the person is dead

questions.text: What is true about the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells along the path of electric current. 

 

The pattern seen in the image is known as Lichtenberg figures or arborescent markings. These patterns are characteristic of lightning injuries and are caused by electrical discharge. When a person is struck by lightning, the electric current leads to the rupture (lysis) of red blood cells in the superficial microvasculature (small blood vessels), which causes the tissues to be stained by hemoglobin. This results in the distinctive fern-like pattern visible on the skin.

 

These markings appear within a few minutes to an hour after the lightning strike and are not true burns. They are superficial, non-blistering, and do not involve thermal injury, which distinguishes them from other types of burns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. They indicate the path taken by the discharge along the major blood vessels: This is incorrect because Lichtenberg figures follow the microvasculature, not major blood vessels. The electric current typically causes superficial damage to the smallest blood vessels.

 

Option C. These are superficial dry burns: Although Lichtenberg figures might be referred to as "burns" colloquially, they are not true burns. They are merely stains caused by the leakage of hemoglobin into the tissue and do not involve thermal damage.

 

Option D. They gradually fade within 24–48 hours if the person is dead: This statement is inaccurate. If the person is dead, the Lichtenberg figures will not fade. They only disappear in survivors, usually within 24–48 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichtenberg figures are caused by the staining of superficial tissues with hemoglobin after electrical injury from a lightning strike. These patterns are not burns and follow the path of microvasculature, not major blood vessels.

questions.text: Treatment of methyl alcohol poisoning includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Forced Alkaline Diuresis

 

Forced Alkaline Diuresis (Option D) is not part of the treatment for methyl alcohol poisoning because it is not effective for excreting strong acids like formic acid. Forced alkaline diuresis is primarily used to enhance the elimination of weak acids, such as barbiturates, chlorpropamide, methotrexate, and salicylates.

 

The treatment of methyl alcohol (methanol) poisoning focuses on preventing the formation of toxic metabolites (formic acid) and removing them from the body. Methyl alcohol is metabolized by the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, which converts it to formaldehyde and subsequently to formic acid, leading to metabolic acidosis and toxic effects. 

 

Other Options:

 

The main treatments are:

 

Option A. Ethanol and Option B. Fomepizole: Both ethanol and fomepizole inhibit alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing methanol from being converted into toxic metabolites.

 

Option C. Hemodialysis: Used to remove methanol and formic acid from the bloodstream, helping to reduce acidosis and systemic toxicity.

 

Note: 

 

Sodium Bicarbonate – Administered to correct metabolic acidosis caused by the accumulation of formic acid.

 

Educational Objective:


Forced alkaline diuresis is ineffective in treating methyl alcohol poisoning because it cannot eliminate strong acids like formic acid. The primary treatments include ethanol or fomepizole, hemodialysis, and sodium bicarbonate for acidosis management.

choices.text: Pharmacologically induced penile erection therapy

questions.text: A forensic expert is reviewing a medicolegal case involving a claim of impotence for marital dispute resolution. Part of the forensic evaluation involves differentiating between psychological and organic causes of erectile dysfunction. The expert plans to recommend a specific test to assist in this determination. Which test is most commonly used to differentiate between psychological and organic erectile dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nocturnal penile tumescence

 

Option B:

 

Nocturnal penile tumescence (NPT) testing, also known as the "sleep erection test," is used to differentiate between psychological and organic causes of erectile dysfunction. NPT refers to the erections that occur during sleep. Normally, a man has 5–6 erections during sleep, especially during REM—their absence may indicate defect in nerve function or blood supply in the penis (Organic cause). Normal NPT is suggestive of a psychological cause of ED, as it indicates the physiological capability for erection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pharmacologically induced penile erection therapy: Used to assess the ability to achieve an erection but does not specifically differentiate between psychological and organic causes.

 

Option C. Sildenafil induced erection: Useful in assessing response to medication, not in differentiating the cause of ED.

 

Option D. Squeeze technique: More related to premature ejaculation than to differentiating causes of ED.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the use of nocturnal penile tumescence testing in the forensic evaluation of erectile dysfunction. This test is crucial for distinguishing between psychological and organic causes, aiding in medicolegal cases that involve claims related to sexual dysfunction, such as in marital disputes or compensation claims.

choices.text: Pale raised skin at the margins

questions.text: Characteristic of Joule burn include all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Joule burn is Hyperaemic

 

Joule burns are typically pale, not hyperaemic (which would imply an excess of blood in the vessels causing redness). The hyperemia, if present, is very minimal and occurs in the surrounding intact skin due to an inflammatory response. However, the primary burn itself is pale.

 

Other Options:

 

A Joule burn is a type of electrical burn that occurs at the point of contact between the body and an electrical source. It typically presents as a pale burn due to the vasospasm caused by the intense heat of the current. The key characteristics of a Joule burn include:

 

Option A. Round or oval, shallow crater: This is a true characteristic of a Joule burn, where the contact point typically forms a crater-like appearance.

 

Option C. Pale raised skin at the margins: This is also true, as the margins of the burn are typically pale and raised due to vasospasm and tissue damage.

 

Option D. Seen at electric contact point: This is correct, as Joule burns occur at the point where the body comes into contact with the electrical source.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Joule burns are typically pale with minimal hyperemia due to vasospasm caused by the intense heat of electrical contact. These burns are often seen at the point of contact with the electrical source and may form a shallow crater with raised pale margins.

questions.text: A pediatrician evaluating a 6-month-old girl brought in by her mother. The baby has a history of repeated infections, fever, vomiting, and one seizure episode. There's a significant family history: an elder brother passed away at 3 years old from an undiagnosed condition. The baby appears lethargic and hypotonic, with bilateral nystagmus and a cherry red spot visible in both eyes. A blood examination reveals a decreased level of Hexosaminidase A enzyme, prompting the pediatrician to consider a genetic metabolic disorder. What is the most probable diagnosis for this baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tay-Sachs disease

 

Option C:

 

It is a sphingolipidoses or lipid storage disease, due to deficiency of the enzyme Hexosaminidase A. 

 

C/F: Mental retardation, Cherry red spot in the macula and progressive deterioration. Death by 3–4 years

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gaucher’s disease type 1: Due to deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase, C/F: Enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, no mental retardation, no cherry red spot 

 

Option B: Niemann Pick disease: Due to deficiency of Sphingomyelinase. C/F: Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness, hepatosplenomegaly with Cherry red spot in macula. Death by 2 years of age.

 

Option D: Sandhoff’s disease: Due to deficiency of Hexosaminidase A and B, c/f: Neurological deficit and MR with cherry red spot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder characterized by the absence or insufficient activity of an enzyme called Hexosaminidase A, leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside within lysosomes, causing progressive neurological damage.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 68,251.

questions.text: A teenager is brought to the ER with symptoms of increased confusion and lethargy. Lab tests reveal abnormal liver function and significantly elevated serum ammonia levels. His parents note his recent high protein intake, attributed to his athletic activities. Hyperammonemia can disrupt the TCA cycle by depleting a specific intermediate, leading to impaired energy metabolism. Which TCA cycle intermediate is most likely depleted in this scenario, contributing to the cycle's inhibition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) α-ketoglutarate  

 

Option C:

 

 

  • Since ammonia is toxic to CNS, it is important to maintain only traces (10-20 μg/dL) in peripheral blood and it should be effectively detoxified and eliminated from the body.
  • In severely impaired hepatic function or the development of collateral links between the portal and systemic veins in cirrhosis, portal blood bypasses the liver, systemic blood ammonia may attain toxic levels.
  • Symptoms of ammonia intoxication include tremor, slurred speech, blurred vision, coma, and ultimately death.
  • Ammonia may be toxic to the brain in part because it reacts with α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate.
  • The resulting depletion of levels of α-ketoglutarate then impairs function of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle in neurons.

 

 

Other Options:

Option A. Aspartate:  Although aspartate is involved in the urea cycle, its depletion does not directly inhibit the TCA cycle.

 

Option B. Malate:  Malate is a TCA cycle intermediate, but it is not directly depleted by hyperammonemia.

 

Option D. Fumarate:  Fumarate is also part of the TCA cycle but is not the intermediate depleted by hyperammonemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperammonemia can inhibit the TCA cycle by depleting α-ketoglutarate. Ammonia is detoxified in the liver by the urea cycle, which consumes α-ketoglutarate as it combines with ammonia to form glutamate. This process depletes α-ketoglutarate, a critical intermediate in the TCA cycle, leading to impaired energy metabolism and contributing to the symptoms observed.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 291, 292, Lippincott: P 253.

choices.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis
Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens
Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from an environment presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates a peculiar finding shown below. Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

 

The clinical presentation of pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort along with the laboratory findings suggest a diagnosis of lead poisoning. The presence of basophilic stippling in the red blood cells, as observed in the peripheral blood smear, is a hallmark feature of lead poisoning. Basophilic stippling represents aggregates of ribosomal material that remain in red blood cells due to the disruption of heme synthesis caused by lead toxicity.

 

Lead interferes with the activity of several enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway, leading to defective red blood cell maturation and characteristic basophilic stippling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis: Incorrect. While viral infections can affect erythropoiesis, they do not typically lead to the basophilic stippling seen in lead poisoning.

 

Option B. Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, causing intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells: Incorrect. Lead poisoning does not cause intracellular iron accumulation but affects heme synthesis, leading to the formation of ribosomal aggregates within red blood cells, which is reflected as basophilic stippling.

 

Option C. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens: Incorrect. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia typically causes hemolysis and spherocytes in the blood smear but does not result in basophilic stippling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Students should recognize basophilic stippling as a key feature of lead poisoning, resulting from the disruption of heme synthesis and the accumulation of ribosomal material in red blood cells. This is important in diagnosing children exposed to lead, which can lead to significant anemia and other systemic effects

choices.text: Contain regulatory genes, an operator gene, three structural genes and a promoter site
Contain three structural genes, an operator and regulatory gene

questions.text: Regarding the lactose (lac) operon in bacteria, which of the following statements is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Contain regulatory genes, an operator gene, three structural genes and a promoter site.

 

Option C:

 

  • Operon is a unit of gene expression. It includes structural genes, control elements, regulator/inhibitor gene, promoter, and operator areas, e.g., Lac operon.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Contains three structural genes: While true, this option is incomplete as it doesn't mention other critical components of the lac operon.

 

Option B. Contains operator region: This is also correct but incomplete, as the lac operon includes more than just an operator region.

 

Option D. Contains three structural genes, an operator, and a regulatory gene: This option is partially correct but lacks the mention of the promoter site and implies the regulatory gene is part of the operon, whereas it is usually located elsewhere on the chromosome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lac operon is a well-studied example of a gene regulatory system and includes three structural genes (lacZ, lacY, and lacA) that are involved in lactose metabolism. It also has a promoter site where RNA polymerase binds to initiate transcription, an operator site where the lac repressor can bind to inhibit transcription, and regulatory genes (such as the lacI gene that codes for the lac repressor protein) that control the operon's expression.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 636

During a rural health camp, a medical officer is educating the community about the risks associated with snakebites, particularly from venomous species. The officer emphasizes the importance of recognizing features of poisonous snakes for early identification and management. Which of the following characteristics is NOT typically associated with venomous snakes?

 

  1. They are primarily nocturnal in habit.
  2. They have a compressed tail.
  3. They possess solid and stout fangs.

questions.solution:

  1. Nocturnal in habit: This is a common characteristic of many poisonous snakes, allowing them to hunt and avoid predators under the cover of darkness.
  2. Have compressed tail: While some venomous snakes may exhibit a compressed tail, this feature is not a definitive indicator of venomous species and varies among different snake families.

questions.text: In a pathology laboratory, a medical officer is analyzing tissue samples from a deceased pregnant woman who suddenly collapsed and died. The medical history and symptoms prior to death suggest a rare but serious complication. The medical officer decides to use Lendrum's stain in the histopathological examination of the lung tissue. For which type of embolism is Lendrum's stain specifically used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amniotic fluid embolism

 

Option C:

 

Lendrum’s stain (Phloxine-Tartrazine): This stain is useful to detect amniotic fluid embolism deaths, since keratin of amniotic squames is stained red, nuclei blue and cytoplasm yellow.

 

The ‘WHO’ method: It is helpful to demonstrate keratin and mucin-like substances in amniotic fluid embolism.

 

Some important Pointers related to Amniotic Fluid Embolism

 

  • Most of the cases occur during: 1st and 2nd trimester abortion;  Active labor; Amniocentesis; Abdominal trauma
  • Amniotic fluid embolism is a rare, unforeseeable and dreadful complication. This occurs when massive amount of amniotic fluid enters the maternal venous system.
  • There may be tonic-clonic seizures, breathlessness and loss of consciousness. In half the cases, death occurs in the first hour.
  • It causes DIC and fibrin deposition in many organs.
  • Diagnosis is established by demonstration of mucin, lanugo hair, vernix caseosa, fat globules, meconium and fetal squamous cells in cut sections of the lung.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Air embolism: Not identifiable with Lendrum's stain.

 

Option B. Fat embolism: Detected through different staining techniques.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism: The nature of the embolus (e.g., thrombus, fat, air) dictates the staining technique, not the location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lendrum's stain is used in forensic pathology for the identification of amniotic fluid embolism, a critical diagnostic tool in cases of maternal death where this condition is suspected.

 

Cause of Death in Criminal Abortion

 

  • Immediate: Air embolism, fat embolism, amniotic fluid embolism, hemorrhage, vagal inhibition.
  • Delayed (with 2 to 3 days): Septicemia, generalized peritonitis, tetanus, local infection & toxemia.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 410

questions.text: Hatter shake is seen in which poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mercury

 

"Hatter shake," also known as "Danbury tremor" or "glass blower’s shake," is a classic symptom of mercury poisoning. This type of tremor is typically coarse and begins in the hands, later spreading to other parts of the body. The name “Hatter shake” originates from historical cases in hat-makers who were frequently exposed to mercury compounds during the hat-making process. As the tremors become more severe and widespread, they may progress to a condition called “shaking palsy” or concusio mercuralis, where physical tasks become almost impossible due to the intense shaking. This symptom is a distinctive sign of mercury’s effect on the nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead: Lead poisoning affects multiple systems, particularly causing neurotoxicity, abdominal pain, and anemia. However, it does not commonly lead to the coarse tremors seen in mercury poisoning.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning presents with symptoms such as skin changes, peripheral neuropathy, and gastrointestinal distress but does not cause the specific tremor associated with mercury.

 

Option D. Thallium: Thallium poisoning often results in neurological symptoms, including pain, paresthesias, and hair loss (alopecia), but it does not cause the classic coarse tremor known as the "Hatter shake."

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Hatter shake" is a classic tremor associated with mercury poisoning, beginning in the hands and potentially spreading throughout the body, where it can progress to shaking palsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the active form of Vitamin D?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 25 (OH) 2 Vit-D

 

Option C:

 

  • It is otherwise called as calcitriol
  • 25-HCC is further hydroxylated at the 1st position by 1-alpha hydroxylase In the kidney → forming 1, 25-dihydroxy cholecalciferol (DHCC).
  • As it contains three hydroxyl groups at 1,3 and 25 positions, it is also called as Calcitriol, which is the active form of vitamin and it is a hormone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cholecalciferol: or vitamin D3: is derived either from 7 dehydrocholesterol or ergosterol by the action of ultraviolet radiations. The cis double bond is then isomerized to a trans double bond to give this.

 

Option B. 24, 25(OH)2 vit-D: formed by hydroxylation of 25HCC at the 24th position, a relatively inactive product.

 

Option D. 25-OH vit-D: The cholecalciferol is transported to liver, hydroxylation at 25th position to form 25-hydroxy cholecalciferol.

 

Educational objective:

 

The active form of vitamin D is 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, also known as calcitriol. It is produced in the kidneys from 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25-OH vit-D), which is the major circulating form and is a marker for vitamin D status in the body. Calcitriol acts as a hormone and regulates calcium and phosphate metabolism in the bones, intestines, and kidneys.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 469.

questions.text: In a case involving suspected arsenic poisoning, a forensic toxicologist is tasked with determining the distribution of arsenic within the body of the deceased. To ascertain the cause of death and gather evidence for potential legal proceedings, it is crucial to identify which organ would likely contain the greatest concentration of arsenic following exposure. Based on the typical accumulation pattern of heavy metals like arsenic in the human body, where would the greatest concentration of arsenic likely be found?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Liver

 

  • The liver is the organ where the greatest concentration of arsenic is likely to be found in the case of arsenic poisoning.
  • The liver is a key organ for detoxification and metabolism in the body, and it often bears the brunt of toxic substances, including heavy metals like arsenic.
  • Arsenic is metabolized in the liver, where it can bind to cellular components and disrupt metabolic processes.
  • This accumulation can lead to liver damage and failure, which are common outcomes of significant arsenic exposure.
  • Therefore, in forensic toxicology, the liver is a primary target for analysis in suspected cases of arsenic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle: While arsenic can be distributed throughout the body's tissues, including muscle, it does not typically accumulate in muscle tissues to the same extent as it does in organs involved in filtration and metabolism, like the liver and kidneys.

 

Option B. Kidney: The kidneys also play a role in filtering blood and excreting waste products, including arsenic. Although arsenic can accumulate in the kidneys and cause damage, the liver generally shows higher concentrations due to its central role in metabolism and detoxification.

 

Option D. Brain: The brain is less likely to accumulate high concentrations of arsenic compared to the liver. While arsenic can cross the blood-brain barrier and potentially cause neurological effects, it is not the primary site of accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arsenic accumulates predominantly in the liver due to its role in metabolism and detoxification. In cases of arsenic poisoning, the liver often shows the highest concentration of the toxin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old hospital worker presents with tingling and numbness in his extremities and has a dry, scaly scalp. He has been undergoing treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis with antitubercular therapy (ATT) for the past four months. Considering the symptoms and his medical background, which vitamin deficiency is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

Option A:

 

  • Isonicotinic acid hydrazide (isoniazid) is an antituberculosis drug.
  • It inhibits pyridoxal kinase thereby reducing the formation of PLP causing vitamin B6 deficiency.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Vitamin B2: C/F are limited to skin and mucous membranes. It includes glossitis, magenta colored tongue, cheilosis, angular stomatitis and circumcorneal congestion.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1: Dementia, macrocytic anemia (folate deficiency), liver disease, depression, cardiomyopathy and pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Includes Megaloblastic anemia, Homocystinuria, Demyelination, Subacute combined degeneration and Achlorhydria. ATT doesn’t interfere with other vitamins.

 

Educational objective:

 

Isoniazid, a common medication used in antitubercular therapy (ATT), is known to cause vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency as a side effect. This deficiency can lead to peripheral neuropathy, presenting as tingling and numbness in the extremities, which aligns with the patient's symptoms. The dry, scaly scalp might also be related to broader nutritional deficiencies or dermatological effects associated with the treatment.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 483.

questions.text: A research team studying bacterial genetics exposes a culture to a chemical mutagen. The bacteria, which typically require minimal nutrition, are then plated on a nutrient-rich medium. Individual colonies that form are subsequently tested for their ability to grow on a minimal medium. Those failing to thrive are identified as mutants, and genomic sequencing reveals a deletion of a two-nucleotide segment in their DNA. What type of mutation does this deletion most likely produce?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Frameshift mutation  

 

Option A:

 

  • Frameshift mutation: It causes deletion of nucleotides which are not multiples of 3 and the genetic code will be read differently from that or till another alteration in the DNA restores the original reading frame (e.g., addition of two base pairs or deletion of another base pair).

  • This mutation often results in a truncated protein.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Conservative mutation (Incorrect): It is a Missense mutation which leads to the substitution of a given amino acid with a chemically similar amino acid.

 

Option C. Missense mutation (Incorrect): It leads to the replacement of a given amino acid with a different amino acid.

 

Option D. Nonsense mutation (Incorrect): It introduces a stop codon instead of a codon specific for an amino acid, causing premature chain termination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deletion of a two-nucleotide segment within a gene's coding region typically results in a frameshift mutation. Because the genetic code is read in triplets (codons), removing two nucleotides alters the reading frame downstream of the mutation, likely changing every subsequent amino acid in the protein product. This shift can lead to a nonfunctional protein due to extensive missense mutations and the potential introduction of a premature stop codon (nonsense mutation).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 417-418.

choices.text: High voltage burns

questions.text: A 45-year-old electrician is brought to the emergency department after sustaining injuries from a high-voltage electrical line during work. Upon examination, the patient has areas of skin that are leathery with a distinctive pattern that resembles crocodile skin. The areas are primarily localized along the pathway of the current across his body. The medical officer is discussing the case with residents and asks them to identify the condition that typically presents this type of skin appearance. What is the "crocodile skin" appearance commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High voltage burns

 

Option C:

 

The "crocodile skin" appearance is characteristic of high voltage electrical burns. This pattern results from the intense heat generated by the electrical current, which causes full-thickness skin damage that coagulates and contracts the skin, often leaving a patterned effect that resembles the hide of a crocodile.

 

 

Exogenous electric burns

 

  • The term exogenous burns is used If the contact with electric source is not good or is less firm (or in case of high voltage source there may not even be any contact but the victim is just nearby).
  • The current jumps the gap between the source and the skin in the form of a spark and causes the outer skin keratin to melt over a small area.  On cooling,  the  keratin  gets  condensed  into  a  hard brownish nodule and this is termed as the so-called spark burn or Flash burn.
  • In cases of High Voltage sources, the currents can jump several millimeters across air and cause multiple spark burns over a large area. This molten keratin over these area fuses into multiple hard brownish nodules on cooling and resembles skin of the crocodile called crocodile burns.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Drowning does not result in such patterns on the skin; changes related to drowning include wrinkling or washing away of the superficial skin layers.

 

Option B. Mummification refers to the dehydration of the body after death, leading to dry, shrunken, and leathery skin.

 

Option D. Electric shocks can cause a variety of skin appearances depending on the voltage, but the specific "crocodile skin" appearance is typically associated with high voltage injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crocodile skin appearance is a kind of exogenous burns seen due to Electric current in high voltage sources when there is no direct contact with body. The term electric shock is used when the person touches an electrical source, whereas, Crocodile skin appearance occurs when the person is near the high voltage source but not in direct contact. 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 330-331

questions.text: A middle aged man from West Bengal presents with paraesthesia of hands and feet, hyperkeratosis, lines in the nails and rain drop pigmentation in the hands. The most likely causative toxin for the above mentioned symptoms is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arsenic

 

The symptoms mentioned in the question are classic features of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Chronic Arsenic poisoning: It is insidious in nature. The onset of symptoms usually  occurs  after 2–8  weeks of exposure.  Chronic  poisoning  may  occur among persons engaged in smelting and refining of ores and in the subliming of arsenic in the manufacture of weed killers, dyes etc.

 

Clinical Features of Chronic Arsenic poisoning:

 

  1. GIT symptoms: loss of weight, malaise, loss of appetite, salivation, colicky pain, diarrhoea and vomiting.
  2. Liver: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
  3. Skin symptoms: usually begin with a persistent erythematous flush leading to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Hyperkeratosis is most prominent in the distal parts of the body. Pigmentation is patchy (‘raindrops pigmentation). Skin cancer (Squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma) also occurs.
  4. Nails: Aldrich Mees lines (transverse  white  striae  of  the fingernails) may also be seen.
  5. Hairs: Alopecia occurs
  6. Hematological: Anemia, leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia and Bone marrow hypoplasia are  seen.  Anemia is normocytic and normochromic
  7.  Peripheral neuropathy: Sensory  and  motor  polyneuritis (sensory  symptoms  usually  predominate)  manifesting  as numbness and tingling in a ‘stocking glove’ distribution.
  8. Blackfoot disease: Due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.
  9. Encephalopathy
  10. Nephritis

 

Other Options:

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic arsenic poisoning presents with distinctive symptoms such as paraesthesia, hyperkeratosis, Aldrich Mees lines, and raindrop pigmentation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

questions.text: A middle-aged man from West Bengal presents to the clinic with complaints of numbness and tingling in his hands and feet, thickened patches of skin, distinctive lines across his nails, and "raindrop" pigmentation on his hands. These symptoms have progressively worsened over several months. Given the patient's geographic location and the constellation of symptoms, you suspect chronic exposure to a toxic substance. Which of the following toxins is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arsenic

 

Option B:

 

The symptoms mentioned in the question are classic features of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Chronic Arsenic poisoning: It is insidious in nature. The onset of symptoms usually occurs after 2–8 weeks of exposure.  Chronic poisoning may occur among persons engaged in smelting and refining of ores and in the subliming of arsenic in the manufacture of weed killers, dyes etc.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  1. GIT symptoms: loss of weight, malaise, loss of appetite, salivation, colicky pain, diarrhoea and vomiting.
  2. Liver: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
  3. Skin symptoms: usually begin with a persistent erythematous flush leading to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Hyperkeratosis is most prominent in the distal parts of the body. Pigmentation is patchy (‘raindrops pigmentation). Skin cancer (Squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma) also occurs.
  4. Nails: Aldrich Mees lines (transverse white striae of the fingernails) may also be seen.
  5. Hairs: Alopecia occurs
  6. Hematological: Anemia, leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia and Bone marrow hypoplasia are seen.  Anemia is normocytic and normochromic.
  7. Peripheral neuropathy:  Sensory and motor polyneuritis (sensory  symptoms  usually  predominate)  manifesting  as numbness and tingling in a ‘stocking glove’ distribution.
  8. Blackfoot disease: Due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.
  9. Encephalopathy
  10. Nephritis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lead exposure typically presents with gastrointestinal distress, anemia, and neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, but it does not commonly cause hyperkeratosis or "raindrop" pigmentation.

 

Option C. Thallium poisoning is known for causing severe alopecia (hair loss) and painful neuropathies, but it does not typically present with raindrop pigmentation or Mees' lines.

 

Option D. Mercury exposure can lead to neurological symptoms and acrodynia (pink disease), but it is not associated with the specific dermatological findings seen in arsenic poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dermatological manifestations of chronic arsenic poisoning - Rash resembling fading measles rash, Speckled brown pigmentation, mostly on the skin flexures, temples, shoulders, eyelids and neck (raindrop pigmentation). Macular areas of depigmentation may appear on normal/hyperpigmented skin (leucomelanosis). Hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles with irregular thickening of the nails and development of white bands of opacity in the nails of fingers and toes (called Aldrich-Mees lines). Brittle nails and alopecia are also seen.

questions.text: While studying the regulation of metabolic pathways, a medical student comes across the concept of allosteric control, particularly its role in enzyme activity. Allosteric enzymes have unique characteristics that differentiate them from other enzymes. Which of the following statements accurately describes a property of allosteric enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Allosteric control with negative feedback is found in many metabolic pathways

 

Explanation:

 

Allosteric control with negative feedback is indeed a key regulatory mechanism in many metabolic pathways, making option D correct. In negative feedback allosteric regulation, the end product of a metabolic pathway inhibits an enzyme at an earlier step in the pathway, effectively shutting down production when sufficient product has accumulated. Classic examples include:

  1. Inhibition of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) by ATP in glycolysis
  2. Inhibition of aspartate transcarbamoylase (ATCase) by CTP in pyrimidine synthesis

 

Other options: 

 

 

Option A. Allosteric effectors bind allosteric enzymes at their active sites: This statement is incorrect. By definition, allosteric effectors bind to sites distinct from the active site, called allosteric sites. The term "allosteric" comes from "allo" (other) and "steric" (space or structure), referring to binding at a site other than the active site. When an allosteric effector binds, it induces a conformational change that alters the activity of the enzyme.

 

Option B. Allosteric enzymes possess secondary structure: This statement is correct but not distinctive. All proteins, including enzymes (allosteric or not), possess secondary structure elements such as alpha helices and beta sheets. This is not a unique characteristic of allosteric enzymes.

 

Option C. Allosteric control is irreversible: This is incorrect. Allosteric regulation is typically reversible, allowing for rapid adaptation to changing cellular conditions. When the concentration of the allosteric effector decreases, the enzyme can return to its original conformation and activity state.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Allosteric enzymes are typically oligomeric proteins with multiple subunits that exhibit cooperativity and sigmoidal kinetics rather than the hyperbolic kinetics of Michaelis-Menten enzymes. Their activity can be modulated by effectors binding at sites distinct from the active site, causing conformational changes that alter the enzyme's catalytic efficiency. This provides a rapid, reversible mechanism for regulating metabolic pathways in response to changing cellular needs, with negative feedback being one of the most common control mechanisms in metabolism.

questions.text: In a medicolegal investigation regarding a case of alleged medical malpractice during early pregnancy, a medical officer is reviewing laboratory data to assess the progression of the pregnancy. Understanding the normal trends of hormonal changes during pregnancy is crucial in this context. At what gestational age do maternal human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) levels typically reach their maximum in a normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8 to 10 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

In a normal pregnancy, the maternal hCG levels typically peak between 8 to 10 weeks of gestation. After this period, the levels generally stabilize or decrease slightly.

 

Some important pointers related to IMMUNOLOGICAL TESTS –

 

  • The hormone chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) and human chorionic somatomamnotropin (HCS) are secreted by the syncytial trophoblastic cells into the fluids of the mother.
  • It can be detected in maternal blood on about the 8th day after impregnation.
  • The rate of secretion rises rapidly to reach a maximum about seven weeks after conception, and decreases to a relatively low volume by 16 weeks after conception.
  • Because they are convenient and very reliable (accuracy 98% ), they have replaced bioassays for routine screening.
  • An early morning urine specimen will contain the highest level of HCG and is preferable for testing. Tests are positive 12 to 15 days after implantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the typical timeline for peak hCG levels in early pregnancy (8-10 weeks), which is an important marker for confirming and monitoring the progression of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, who recently arrived in India from China for a vacation, visits a local hospital complaining of diarrhea, vomiting, and an unusually rapid heartbeat. He mentions that these symptoms started a few days after his arrival. The attending cardiologist performs an ECG, which indicates arrhythmia, and an echocardiogram, which shows cardiac enlargement. Based on the patient's clinical presentation and the investigations, which of the following nutrient deficiencies and associated disorders is most likely to be affecting this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenium deficiency- Keshan disease

 

Option A:

 

  • Selenium is an important trace element with normal serum level ranges from 50–100 mg/dL.
  • Impairments in human selenoproteins have been implicated in tumorigenesis, atherosclerosis and selenium deficiency cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease), characterized by multifocal myocardial necrosis, cardiac arrythmias and cardiac enlargement.
  • Isolated selenium deficiency results in liver necrosis, cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy and muscular dystrophy.
  • Selenium toxicity is called Selenosis, symptoms include hair loss, falling of nails, diarrhea, weight loss, and garlicky odor in breath.
  • Kashin-beck disease is characterized by degenerative osteoarthrosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Copper deficiency - Wilson disease: Incorrect because Wilson's disease is caused by copper accumulation, not deficiency.

 

Option C. Selenium deficiency - Acrodermatitis enteropathica: Incorrect because Acrodermatitis enteropathica is associated with zinc deficiency, not selenium.

 

Option D. Copper toxicity - Menkes Kinky-hair syndrome: Incorrect as Menkes disease is a disorder of copper deficiency, not toxicity, and it typically presents in infancy with brittle, kinky hair, growth failure, and developmental delay, not primarily with cardiac symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keshan disease is a cardiomyopathy caused by selenium deficiency. It is characterized by multifocal myocardial necrosis leading to cardiac enlargement and heart failure, which can present as arrhythmias and are consistent with the patient's symptoms and echocardiogram findings. Keshan disease was first identified in regions of China with low selenium soil content.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with characteristic kinky hair and growth retardation, and after thorough investigation, he is diagnosed with Menkes syndrome. Considering the enzymatic and genetic background of this disorder, which enzyme and cofactor are likely to be deficient, and what gene is typically mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lysyl oxidase and copper             

 

Option D: 

 

  • Menkes syndrome, characterized by kinky hair and growth retardation, results from a dietary deficiency of copper, an essential cofactor for the enzyme lysyl oxidase that functions in formation of the covalent cross-links that strengthen collagen fibers.
  • Defects in ATP7A result in Menkes disease

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Methionine synthase, magnesium, ATP7B: Methionine synthase requires vitamin B12 as a cofactor, not magnesium. ATP7B mutations are associated with Wilson's disease, not Menkes syndrome.

 

Option B. Glutamyl aminopeptidase, magnesium, ATP7A: Glutamyl aminopeptidase does not typically require magnesium as a cofactor, and ATP7A is associated with copper transport, not magnesium.

 

Option C. Lysyl hydroxylase, copper, ATP7B: While lysyl hydroxylase is a copper-dependent enzyme, mutations in ATP7B cause Wilson's disease, which is different from Menkes syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Menkes syndrome is a disorder of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, leading to a deficiency in copper absorption and transport. Copper is a necessary cofactor for the enzyme lysyl oxidase, which is critical for the formation and maintenance of connective tissues. A deficiency in lysyl oxidase activity due to inadequate copper levels results in the characteristic clinical manifestations of Menkes syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer comes to the clinic reporting chronic diarrhea and the development of dry, scaly skin lesions around his neck over the last three months. He has an erratic dietary pattern but consumes large amounts of jowar (sorghum), his primary crop, and has done so for over a decade and a half. Based on his diet and symptoms, which enzyme's inhibition is most likely responsible for the clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase

 

The patient presents with classic signs of pellagra: chronic diarrhea and dermatitis (dry, scaly skin lesions around the neck, likely "Casal's necklace"). While pellagra is classically associated with maize (corn) consumption, it can also occur in populations whose staple diet is sorghum (jowar).

 

Sorghum contains high quantities of leucine. Excess leucine inhibits quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase (QPRT), a key enzyme in the conversion pathway from tryptophan to nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). This inhibition leads to decreased synthesis of niacin (vitamin B3) from tryptophan, resulting in niacin deficiency and the development of pellagra ("leucine pellagra").

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transaminase: These enzymes (such as ALT and AST) are involved in amino acid metabolism through transferring amino groups. They are not specifically involved in the tryptophan-to-niacin pathway and their inhibition would not explain the clinical presentation of pellagra.

 

Option B. Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase: Correct - This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of quinolinic acid to nicotinic acid mononucleotide in the pathway from tryptophan to NAD+. Its inhibition by excess leucine in sorghum leads to niacin deficiency manifestations.

 

Option C. Histidase: This enzyme converts histidine to urocanic acid in histidine metabolism. Histidase deficiency causes histidinemia, characterized by elevated histidine levels and symptoms like speech delay and developmental issues, not pellagra.

 

Option D. Tryptophan pyrrolase (now commonly called tryptophan dioxygenase): This enzyme catalyzes the first step in tryptophan catabolism, converting tryptophan to N-formylkynurenine. While involved in the tryptophan pathway, its inhibition is not specifically associated with the leucine-induced pellagra seen in sorghum consumption.

 

Educational objective:

 

Pellagra is a disease caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, characterized by the "4 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and death if untreated. While commonly associated with maize-based diets, "leucine pellagra" can develop in populations consuming sorghum as a staple food due to leucine's inhibition of QPRT, blocking the endogenous synthesis of niacin from tryptophan. This case highlights the importance of understanding dietary factors that can interfere with specific metabolic pathways.

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic in New Delhi, a 5-year-old child is diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, a severe muscle-wasting disease. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the promoter region of the gene responsible for producing dystrophin, a crucial muscle protein. Considering the role of promoter regions in gene expression, which of the following is the most likely consequence of this mutation on dystrophin production?

Ans. A) Initiation of dystrophin transcription will be defective 

 

Option A:  

                                                                          

  • Mutations in the promoter region prevents the formation of RNA polymerase II transcription complex 🡪decrease in the initiation of mRNA synthesis.

  • A deficiency of dystrophin mRNA will lead to deficiency of the dystrophin protein.

 

Explanation:

Option C: Capping and splicing are post-transcriptional modifications and generally not directly affected by promoter mutations.

 

Option D: Polyadenylation (tailing) is another post-transcriptional event typically not influenced by mutations in the promoter region.

A mutation in the promoter region of the dystrophin gene with Duchenne muscular dystrophy, is likely to impair the initiation of dystrophin transcription. This is because the promoter region is essential for the start of transcription, and its mutation disrupts the normal production of dystrophin, a key protein for muscle function.

questions.text: The below image shows:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heat stiffening

 

The image depicts the pugilistic or boxer's attitude, which is caused by heat stiffening. This posture results from exposure to high temperatures, such as in cases of severe burns. The intense heat causes muscle proteins to coagulate, leading to the flexion of muscles, particularly in the arms and legs, giving the appearance of a boxer’s stance. This is a direct result of heat stiffening due to burns and is not related to rigor mortis, cadaveric spasm, or gas stiffening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rigor Mortis: Incorrect. Rigor mortis is the postmortem stiffening of muscles due to ATP depletion, which affects the entire body uniformly after death. It does not result in the distinctive flexed "boxer" pose.

 

Option C. Cadaveric spasm: Incorrect. Cadaveric spasm is an instantaneous stiffening of muscles that occurs at the moment of death, often seen in violent deaths, but it does not produce the pugilistic attitude seen here.

 

Option D. Gas stiffening: Incorrect. Gas stiffening occurs when gases build up in the body during decomposition, causing bloating, but it does not cause the distinctive flexed posture seen in heat stiffening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that the pugilistic or boxer's attitude is caused by heat stiffening, where intense heat leads to muscle contraction, creating a flexed posture often seen in burn victims.

questions.text: A neonate presents with marked hypotonia, necessitating tube feeding, and displays distinct facial characteristics, including almond-shaped eyes and downturned mouth corners, suggestive of a genetic disorder. Given the clinical presentation and the suspicion of Prader-Willi syndrome, the physician orders chromosomal analysis and DNA testing to investigate a specific chromosome 15 abnormality and potential genomic imprinting issues. Which molecular process, occurring at the 5th position of cytidine and often associated with gene silencing, is most relevant to the testing ordered for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DNA methylation

 

Option D:

 

  • DNA methylation occurs mainly at CpG dinucleotides that often cluster in the upstream promoter regions of genes (CpG islands).

  • Chromosomes subject to genomic imprinting might have different DNA methylation patterns on the homologue transmitted from mother versus that transmitted by father, producing balanced expression which is disrupted in disorders such as Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gene conversion involves the process where one DNA sequence is converted to another, which is not directly related to the epigenetic silencing observed in Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Option B: Sister chromatid exchange is a mechanism where identical sister chromatids exchange genetic material during cell division, not typically associated with gene silencing or the pathology of Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Option C: Gene rearrangement refers to the reorganization of genetic material within the genome, which can play a role in certain diseases but is not the primary mechanism behind Prader-Willi syndrome, which involves specific epigenetic modifications like DNA methylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA methylation, particularly at the 5th carbon position of cytosine bases (5-methylcytosine), is a key epigenetic modification that can lead to gene silencing. In the context of Prader-Willi syndrome, this modification is relevant because the disorder is often associated with the loss of paternally inherited genes on chromosome 15 due to deletions or alterations in genomic imprinting, where DNA methylation plays a crucial role.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 582.

questions.text: A patient undergoing long-term anticoagulation therapy with warfarin is being assessed for vitamin supplementation. Given warfarin's mechanism of action as a vitamin K antagonist, the healthcare provider is considering which amino acid's modification is vitamin K-dependent and thus could be affected by this treatment.

Ans. A) Glutamate

Option D. Proline: Post-translational modifications of proline residues, such as hydroxylation, are important in collagen synthesis but are not related to vitamin K.

Vitamin K is essential for the post-translational carboxylation of glutamate residues on clotting factors, which allows them to bind calcium and participate effectively in the blood coagulation process. Knowledge of this biochemical process is important in understanding the mechanism of action of anticoagulants that function as vitamin K antagonists, such as warfarin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents to the emergency department with severe pain, restlessness, hypertension, tachycardia, and sweating after being stung by a scorpion. The sting site is red and swollen, with no signs of necrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer prazosin

 

Option C:

 

Patient is bitten by a scorpion bite and is having symptoms of autonomic storm (restlessness, hypertension, tachycardia, sweating), which is treated by Prazosin.

 

 Clinical Manifestations of Scorpion bite:

 

Main manifestation of scorpion bite is adrenergic (autonomic storm). Sometimes Cholinergic (muscarinic) storms occur.

 

  • Adrenergic Storm: Tachycardia, peripheral vasoconstriction, hypertension, diaphoresis, hyperthermia, tachypnea, mydriasis, tremor, convulsions.
  • Cholinergic syndrome: Salivation, sweating, urinary incontinence, diarrhea), miosis, bronchospasm, bradycardia with hypotension and, priapism in males.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Administer antivenom immediately: Antivenom is given only in cases of severe envenomation with significant systemic symptoms, such as respiratory distress, cardiovascular instability etc.

 

Option B. Apply a tourniquet proximal to the sting site: Applying a tourniquet can worsen tissue damage, delay proper wound care, and increase the risk of complications.

 

Option D. Cleanse the wound and apply ice packs: For cases with mild local symptoms, wound cleansing to prevent infection and the application of ice packs or cold compresses to the sting site can help alleviate pain and reduce swelling. However, in cases of significant systemic symptoms like restlessness, hypertension, and tachycardia, addressing the autonomic effects with prazosin is more crucial. The wound care is secondary, and ice pack can be applied later on.

 

Note - While ice packs are recommended in scorpion bite, it is not to be given in snake bite. Snake venom can contain enzymes that cause tissue damage and affect blood circulation. Cold temperature can constrict blood vessels and worsen the local damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of Scorpion bite:

 

  • Cold compress or Ice pack
  • Prazosin therapy–a post-synaptic alpha1, adreno-receptor antagonist–is the first line of management. It suppresses sympathetic outflow.
  • Scorpion Antivenom: Anti-venom has to be given within 30 minutes of sting to be effective. So useful only in limited cases which present very early. Also, it is reserved for cases of severe envenomation only.

 

Ref: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3/e. Pg 534

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who was working in the fields all day, collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. His skin was dry and hot, face was flushed, pulse was fast and thready. Which of the following symptoms are least likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sweating

 

  • The above case scenario is indicative of Heat Stroke.
  • It is very clear from the question that patient suffered a heat related illness (working in the fields all day, collapsed on a hot summer afternoon).
  • The next step is to know whether it is heat stroke (a life threatening emergency) or other milder forms of heat related illness.
  • The clinical features of “collapse”, “thready pulse” indicate a severe illness.
  • In milder forms of heat illness, the pulse will be strong, moreover the chances of collapse are less.
  • Also, a very characteristic sign is “Dry skin”.
  • In milder forms of heat illness, the skin will be moist due to sweating, but in heat stroke it is dry due to the absence of sweating.
  • Hence it is a case of heat stroke, and answer is sweating.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hot skin, Option B. Hypotension and Option C. Temperature 105.2⁰F. All are the typical abnormalities seen in heat stroke as explained in learning objective below.

 

Learning Objective:

 

GENERALIZED EFFECTS OF HEAT

questions.text: In a case study involving the analysis of a new drug's mechanism of action, it's observed that the drug inhibits an enzyme by resembling the enzyme's natural substrate and competing for the active site. Given this mode of inhibition, how would this type of enzyme inhibition be classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Competitive inhibition

 

  • Inhibitor molecules are competing with the normal substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme, because the inhibitor is a structural analogue of the substrate.

           E + S <-> E–S → E + P

           E + I  <-> E–I

  • Since E-I (enzyme–inhibitor complex) can react only to reform the enzyme and inhibitor, the number of enzyme molecules available for E-S formation is reduced.

 

 

  • Competitive inhibition is reversible or excess substrate abolishes the inhibition.
  • The Km is increased in presence of a competitive inhibitor, thus the affinity of the enzyme towards the substrate is apparently decreased and Vmax is not changed.     

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Non-competitive inhibition: Inhibitors have no structural resemblance to the substrate.

 

Option C. Feedback inhibition: The activity of the enzyme is inhibited by the product of the reaction.

 

Option D. Allosteric inhibition: The inhibitor is not a substrate analog.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor molecule resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the enzyme's active site. This type of inhibition can be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate, as both the substrate and inhibitor compete for the same site on the enzyme.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 59.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who has inherited one mutant allele of the BRCA1 gene has a 60% risk of developing breast cancer by age 50. The BRCA1 gene encodes a protein that plays a crucial role in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. Which DNA repair process is most likely impaired by a deficiency in BRCA1 protein function?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Homologous recombination

 

Option D:

 

  • BRCA1 plays an important role in the repair of double-strand breaks.

  • Since homologous recombination requires a cleavage of both strands of a DNA molecule → deficiency of this gene/protein would affect the event of homologous recombination.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Removal of thymine dimers: This is generally managed by nucleotide excision repair, not by homologous recombination.

 

Option B. Removal of RNA primers: RNA primers are removed during DNA replication, a process unrelated to the repair function of BRCA1.

 

Option C. Removal of carcinogen adducts: Like thymine dimers, carcinogen adducts are typically addressed by nucleotide excision repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA1 protein is fundamentally involved in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks primarily through homologous recombination, a critical process during cell division that ensures the accurate repair of DNA to prevent mutations that could lead to cancer. When BRCA1 function is compromised, the efficiency of homologous recombination repair is significantly reduced, which increases the risk of genomic instability and contributes to cancer predisposition, particularly breast and ovarian cancers.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  P 389-390.

questions.text: In OPC poisoning, treatment was done with atropine and pralidoxime. Hyperthermia occurs. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atropine Toxicity

 

Atropine is an anticholinergic drug used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning to counteract the effects of excessive acetylcholine. However, excessive doses of atropine can lead to atropine toxicity, which includes symptoms of anticholinergic syndrome such as hyperthermia (due to reduced sweating), tachycardia, dry skin, flushing, and confusion.

 

In OPC poisoning, the cholinergic effects cause excessive sweating and a decrease in body temperature. When atropine is administered in large doses, the opposite effect occurs: inhibition of sweating leads to hyperthermia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspiration Pneumonia: While this is a potential complication of OPC poisoning, it would not directly cause hyperthermia. It would more likely lead to respiratory symptoms.

 

Option C. Oximes toxicity: Oximes (e.g., pralidoxime) are used to reactivate cholinesterase but are not commonly associated with hyperthermia as a side effect.

 

Option D. Cyanosis: Cyanosis refers to a bluish discoloration due to inadequate oxygenation and is unrelated to hyperthermia. It would not cause an increase in body temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine toxicity can cause hyperthermia due to its anticholinergic effects, which inhibit sweating and increase body temperature. In the treatment of OPC poisoning, careful monitoring of atropine dosage is essential to avoid these toxic effects.

questions.text: In a case of heavy metal poisoning, the emergency department team is considering the use of British Anti-Lewisite (BAL) as a chelating agent. Understanding the specific indications for BAL is crucial for effective treatment. For which of the following heavy metal poisonings is BAL not indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cadmium

 

Option C:

 

BAL (British Anti-Lewisite) is not effective in treating cadmium poisoning. BAL is primarily used for chelation therapy in lead, mercury, and arsenic poisonings. The complex of the agent and metal is more water-soluble than the metal itself, resulting in higher renal excretion of the complex. They can form stable, soluble complexes with calcium and certain heavy metals.

 

Chelating Agents - are used as specific antidotes against some heavy metal poisoning, as they have greater affinity for the metals as compared to the endogenous enzymes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lead: BAL is effective.

 

Option B. Mercury: BAL is used as a chelator.

 

Option D. Arsenic: BAL is indicated for arsenic poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAL (British anti-lewisite, dimercaprol):

 

  • It is used in arsenic, lead, bismuth, copper, mercury, gold and other heavy metal poisoning.
  • Many heavy metals have affinity for sulfhydryl (–SH) radicals, combine with them in tissues and deprive the body of the use of respiratory enzymes. BAL has two unsaturated –SH groups which combine with the metal and thus prevent the union of the metal with the –SH group of the respiratory enzyme system.
  • Dose: 10% solution in oil, 3–5 mg/kg IM 4 hourly for 2 days, 6 hourly on 3rd day and then 12 hourly for next 10 days.
  • Side effects: Nausea, vomiting, headache and hypertension.
  • Contraindicated in liver damage, G-6-PD deficient individuals, and cadmium and iron poisoning (since dimercaprol-cadmium and dimercaprol-iron complex is itself toxic).

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 518

Child born through artificial insemination
Woman claims the child as her own
Child born out of wedlock

questions.text: In a medicolegal case involving disputed inheritance rights, a forensic expert is reviewing a situation where the legitimacy of a child's parentage is being questioned. The term "suppositious child" is used in the legal documents pertaining to the case. Understanding this term is crucial for the medical officer in providing an expert opinion. What is a "suppositious child"?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Woman claims the child as her own

 

Option C:

 

A "suppositious child" refers to a child whom a woman falsely claims as her own, often in legal disputes or cases of disputed parentage. It involves a false assertion of maternity. Mostly used for blackmailing (by claiming that she is pregnant by him to compel marriage. She may produce a suppositious child to extort money).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Child who is born after the father dies - This describes a posthumous child, not a suppositious child.

 

Option B. Child born through artificial insemination - This refers to a method of conception, not the legitimacy of the child's relationship to the parent.

 

Option D. Child born out of wedlock - This refers to the marital status of the parents at the time of the child's birth and does not inherently imply that the child is suppositious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the legal concept of a suppositious child, which involves a false claim of maternity by a woman. This is done for obtaining money or for the purpose of claiming property or blackmailing a man or bringing a charge of breech of promise of marriage against a man. DNA fingerprinting will be conclusive.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 397

questions.text: What does this diagram best illustrate about the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotic cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alternate splicing

 

Option B:

                                      

  • Eukaryotic mRNA undergoes several modifications such as 5' Capping, 3’ polyadenylation and splicing before it is exported from the nucleus to the cytoplasm protein synthesis.

  • Tissue-specific protein isoforms can result from the same pre -mRNA through differential co-transcriptional processing, particularly the use of alternative splice sites.

  • E.g.: Tropomyosin (TM) regulates the functions of actin in both muscle and nonmuscle cells. Its pre-mRNA undergoes tissue-specific differential splicing resulting in different TM isoforms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. mRNA editing: It is a post-transcriptional modification of mRNA, which is seen in apolipoprotein (apo) B of chylomicrons and VLDL.

 

Option C. Translation of mRNA: Is the mechanism of regulation of translation by phosphorylation of the eukaryotic translation initiation factor, eIF-2.

 

Option D. RNA interference: It is a mechanism of gene silencing either by repression of translation or increased degradation causing decreased expression of mRNA and it plays an important role in cell proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alternate splicing, a process by which different combinations of exons are joined (or spliced) together to generate multiple distinct mRNA transcripts from a single gene. This results in the production of different protein isoforms from the same DNA sequence, increasing the diversity of proteins that a single gene can produce.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 457

questions.text: During a forensic seminar on genetic inheritance and its implications in criminal profiling, a medical officer is discussing the concept of atavism. Understanding this concept is crucial in the analysis of genetic traits that might be significant in certain forensic investigations. What is atavism in the context of genetic inheritance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inheritance of features of the grandfather

 

Explanation:

 

Atavism refers to the inheritance of ancestral or primitive traits or characteristics that resemble those of a grandparent or earlier ancestor. It involves the reemergence of traits from a previous generation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the concept of atavism in genetic inheritance, which involves the reemergence of ancestral traits in descendants.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 397

choices.text: Single nucleotides change in a codon

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with severe abdominal pain, recurrent infections, and a history of chronic hemolytic anemia. On examination, he has a non-healing ulcer on his right leg, and a peripheral blood smear shows abnormally shaped red blood cells. What is the basic genetic defect associated with this disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Single nucleotide change in a codon.

 

Option A:

 

  • This is a case of sickle cell anemia causing production of abnormal Hemoglobin HbS.

  • HbS arises from a point mutation which substitutes thymine for adenine in the 6th codon of the beta-globin chain gene, GTG at the place of GAG 🡪 causes coding of valine [GTG] instead of glutamate [GAG] in position 6 of the Hb beta chain.

  • Resulting Hb: forms polymers under deoxy conditions, exhibits changes in solubility and molecular stability 🡪 these properties are responsible for the profound clinical expressions of the sickling syndromes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Autoantibodies against RBC membrane: are seen in AIHA (autoimmune haemolytic anemia).

 

Option C. Genomic imprinting: in this, expression of some genes depends on whether or not they are inherited maternally or paternally e.g. Angelman syndrome.

 

Option D. Triple nucleotide repeats: These are associated with diseases such as CGG repeat sequence - fragile X syndrome, CAG repeats - Huntington’s chorea, CTG -myotonic dystrophy and CAG in spinobulbar muscular atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a single nucleotide substitution in the β-globin gene, which leads to the replacement of glutamic acid with valine at the sixth position of the β-globin chain. This single amino acid change results in the production of hemoglobin S (HbS), which polymerizes under low-oxygen conditions, causing the red blood cells to take on a sickle shape and leading to hemolytic anemia.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 58, 417.

questions.text: Which of the following options correctly lists the core histone proteins that make up the nucleosome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) H2A, H2B, H3, H4    

    

Option B:                                           

 

  • Histones are a small family of closely related basic proteins.

  • H1 histones are least tightly bound to chromatin.

  • Nucleosomes (core histones) contain four major types of histones: H2A, H2B, H3, H4.

  • H3 and H4 form a tetramer containing two molecules of each (H3–H4)2, while H2A and H2B form dimers (H2A–H2B).

  • Under physiological conditions, these histone oligomers associate to form the histone octamer of the composition (H3–H4)2–(H2A–H2B)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The core histone proteins that constitute the nucleosome are H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 371

questions.text: Identify the plant shown in the image below and the condition it is responsible for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ergot Poisoning

 

The image shows rye plants infected with ergot, a fungal disease caused by Claviceps purpurea. This fungus produces toxic alkaloids known as ergot alkaloids, which can lead to ergotism or ergot poisoning when ingested.

 

Ergot poisoning typically manifests with two types of symptoms:

 

  1. Convulsive ergotism: characterized by seizures, muscle spasms, and hallucinations.
  2. Gangrenous ergotism: due to vasoconstriction, leading to poor circulation, and gangrene in the extremities.

 

Historically, ergotism has been associated with contaminated rye bread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Opioid Poisoning: Incorrect. Opioid poisoning is caused by substances like morphine or heroin and typically presents with CNS depression, miosis, and respiratory depression, not related to ergot-infected rye.

 

Option B. Cannabis Poisoning: Incorrect. Cannabis poisoning involves symptoms like delirium, euphoria, and hallucinations but is not associated with ergot-infected plants.

 

Option D. Dhatura Poisoning: Incorrect. Dhatura poisoning involves anticholinergic symptoms like delirium, dry mouth, mydriasis, and hallucinations, which are unrelated to ergot poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Students should recognize that ergot poisoning arises from consuming rye or other grains infected by the fungus Claviceps purpurea, and it can result in severe vasoconstrictive and neurologic symptoms.

Frigidity of constitution

questions.text: During a criminal investigation involving sexual offenses, a forensic medical examiner is asked to provide expert testimony. The case involves a male suspect who is accused of sexual misconduct, with a specific focus on his inability to deposit semen in the vaginal canal. The examiner is tasked with explaining the correct medical terminology for this condition. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fecundum ab extra

 

Option A:

 

Fecundum ab extra refers to the condition where a male fails to deposit semen within the vaginal canal. This term is significant in cases evaluating sexual performance or dysfunction in a forensic context.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Frigidity of constitution: Refers to a lack of sexual desire, It is the inability to initiate or maintain the sexual arousal pattern in female (absence of desire for sexual intercourse or incapacity to achieve orgasm)

 

Option C. Impotentia ejaculandi: Inability to ejaculate, but does not specifically refer to semen deposition within the vaginal canal.

 

Option D. Impotence quad hoc: Refers to impotence with a specific individual, A male may be impotent with one particular female, but not with another partner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fecundation ab extra: Conception occurring in a woman when the semen was deposited on her thighs or on the vulva.

 

Ref: - Reddy 33/e. Pg 385

choices.text: All the strands will have radioactivity
Half of the DNA will have no radioactivity
Three–fourth of the DNA replicated will have radioactivity

questions.text: In an experiment aimed at understanding DNA replication, a piece of radio-labeled DNA is allowed to undergo two rounds of replication within a non-radioactive medium. This setup is designed to track the distribution of the original radioactive material across the generations of DNA. Based on the known mechanism of semiconservative replication, what would be the expected outcome regarding the radioactivity of the DNA strands after two replication cycles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Half of the DNA will have no radioactivity

 

Explanation:

 

DNA replication follows a semiconservative model, meaning that each daughter DNA molecule retains one original (parental) strand and synthesizes one new strand.

  • After the first round of replication, each of the two daughter DNA molecules contains one radioactive parental strand and one new non-radioactive strand. So, all DNA molecules are partially radioactive.

 

 

  • After the second round of replication, each of these hybrid molecules produces:
    • One hybrid DNA (still containing one radioactive strand)
    • One entirely new DNA molecule (both strands non-radioactive)

 

So now there are four DNA molecules total:

  • Two are hybrid (radioactive + non-radioactive)
  • Two are completely non-radioactive

 

Therefore, half of the DNA molecules (2 out of 4) are non-radioactive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: All strands will have radioactivity — Incorrect. Only the original strands are radioactive, and they are passed on to only half of the DNA molecules after two replications.

 

Option B: No strands will have radioactivity — Incorrect. The original radioactive strands still exist in two of the four DNA molecules.

 

Option D: Three-fourth of the DNA will have radioactivity — Incorrect. Only two out of four DNA molecules (i.e., 50%) retain radioactive material, not 75%.

 

Educational Objective:


Understand the implications of semiconservative DNA replication: in each new round, half of the DNA molecules retain part of the original strand. 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 381-387.

questions.text: Identify which of the following pathways does not produce high-energy phosphate compounds directly helps in comprehending the energy dynamics within the cell.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HMP Pathway.

 

Option B:

 

The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) pathway, also known as the Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP), is primarily involved in the production of NADPH and pentoses (5-carbon sugars) rather than the direct synthesis of high-energy phosphate compounds like ATP or GTP. NADPH is crucial for biosynthetic reactions and antioxidant defense, but the pathway itself does not directly produce high-energy phosphate compounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TCA cycle: This cycle includes steps that produce high-energy phosphate compounds, such as the substrate-level phosphorylation generating GTP.

 

Option C. Glycolysis: Glycolysis directly produces ATP through substrate-level phosphorylation in two steps.

 

Option D. Beta-Oxidation of Fatty Acid - Each cycle of beta-oxidation generates FADH2 and NADH, which contribute to ATP synthesis through oxidative phosphorylation, albeit indirectly. However, considering the overall process and its contribution to ATP generation, it's included among the pathways that produce high-energy compounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pathways which do not synthesize ATP are
 

  • HMP Pathway
  • Rapaport Luebering Cycle
  • Uronic acid pathway
  • Alpha oxidation of Fatty acid
  • Omega Oxidation of fatty acid

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 253.
